0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Pruritus of skin: completely rub lotion into affected areas, repeat as necessary
  • Scabies: apply cream or lotion topically to entire body from the chin down (do not rinse off), 24 h later apply cream or lotion a second time and leave on the skin for 48 h; a cleansing bath should be taken 48 h after the last application

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: not FDA approved in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Pruritus of skin
  • Scabies
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Pediculosis capitis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• avoid application to face, eyes, mouth, or mucous membranes
  • avoid applying to inflamed skin or raw, oozing skin surfaces
  • discontinue use of crotamiton if severe skin irritation develops

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Topical: The mechanisms of the scabicidal and antipruritic actions of crotamiton are not known.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • shake the lotion well before using
  • do not apply to acutely inflamed, raw, or weeping skin
  • (scabies) after taking a bath or shower, apply a thin layer to all body surfaces from the chin down; apply second application 24 hours later; patient should take a bath or shower 48 h after second application; clothing and bed linen should be changed the next morning
  • (pruritus) massage gently into affected areas until completely absorbed; repeat as needed

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CROTAMITON
OVERDOSE: Crotamiton overdose information is limited. Although crotamiton is indicated for topical use only, an intentional ingestion of crotamiton emulsion was reported, causing somnolence, nausea and vomiting, hypotension, generalized seizures, and coma with hyperreflexia and bilateral ankle clonus. ADVERSE EVENTS: Contact dermatitis is the primary adverse effect observed following topical administration of crotamiton.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CROTAMITON
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: May consider activated charcoal with ingestion of crotamiton.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NS, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Seizure disorder: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor respiratory, cardiac, and neurologic function closely. Monitor pulse oximetry and blood pressure.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CROTAMITON
TOXICITY: The highest known dose ingested, of a cream, was 2 grams by a 1.5-year-old and the highest known dose ingested, of a lotion, was 1 ounce by a 2-year- old. THERAPEUTIC: For the treatment of scabies, apply cream or lotion topically to entire body from the chin down (do not rinse off), 24 h later apply cream or lotion a second time and leave on the skin for 48 h; a cleansing bath should be taken 48 h after the last application. Not FDA approved in pediatric patients.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report severe skin irritation.
  • Patient should not apply drug to face, eyes, mouth, or mucous membranes. Drug should not be applied to acutely inflamed, raw, or weeping skin.
  • Tell patient to wash clothing and bed linen the next morning after the last application.
  • Tell patient to take a bath or shower 48 h after second application.
